column2: NOTES FOR LECTURE XVIII
column3: NOTES FOR LECTURE eighteen

column2: Tides are due to incomplete rigidity of bodies revolving round each other under the action of gravitation, and at the same time spinning on their axes.
column3: Tides are due to incomplete rigidity of bodies revolving round each other under the action of gravitation, and at the same time spinning on their axes.

column2: Two spheres revolving round each other can only remain spherical if rigid; if at all plastic they become prolate.
column3: Two spheres revolving round each other can only remain spherical if rigid; if at all plastic they become prolate.

column2: If either rotate on its axis, in the same or nearly the same plane as it revolves, that one is necessarily subject to tides.
column3: If either rotate on its axis, in the same or nearly the same plane as it revolves, that one is necessarily subject to tides.

column2: The axial rotation tends to carry the humps with it, but the pull of the other body keeps them from moving much.
column3: The axial rotation tends to carry the humps with it, but the pull of the other body keeps them from moving much.

column2: Hence the rotation takes place against a pull, and is therefore more or less checked and retarded.
column3: Hence the rotation takes place against a pull, and is therefore more or less checked and retarded.

column2: This is the theory of Von Helmholtz.
column3: This is the theory of Von Helmholtz.

column2: The attracting force between two such bodies is no longer _exactly_ towards the centre of revolution, and therefore Kepler's second law is no longer precisely obeyed: the rate of description of areas is subject to slight acceleration.
column3: The attracting force between two such bodies is no longer underscore exactly underscore towards the centre of revolution, and therefore Kepler's second law is no longer precisely obeyed: the rate of description of areas is subject to slight acceleration.

column2: The effect of this tangential force acting on the tide-compelling body is gradually to increase its distance from the other body.
column3: The effect of this tangential force acting on the tide compelling body is gradually to increase its distance from the other body.

column2: Applying these statements to the earth and moon, we see that tidal energy is produced at the expense of the earth's rotation, and that the length of the day is thereby slowly increasing.
column3: Applying these statements to the earth and moon, we see that tidal energy is produced at the expense of the earth's rotation, and that the length of the day is thereby slowly increasing.

column2: Also that the moon's rotation relative to the earth has been destroyed by past tidal action in it (the only residue of ancient lunar rotation now being a scarcely perceptible libration), so that it turns always the same face towards us.
column3: Also that the moon's rotation relative to the earth has been destroyed by past tidal action in it (the only residue of ancient lunar rotation now being a scarcely perceptible libration), so that it turns always the same face towards us.

column2: Moreover, that its distance from the earth is steadily increasing. This last is the theory of Professor G.H. Darwin.
column3: Moreover, that its distance from the earth is steadily increasing. This last is the theory of Professor g h Darwin.

column2: Long ago the moon must therefore have been much nearer the earth, and the day was much shorter.
column3: Long ago the moon must therefore have been much nearer the earth, and the day was much shorter.

column2: The tides were then far more violent.
column3: The tides were then far more violent.

column2: Halving the distance would make them eight times as high; quartering it would increase them sixty-four-fold.
column3: Halving the distance would make them eight times as high; quartering it would increase them sixty four fold.

column2: A most powerful geological denuding agent.
column3: A most powerful geological denuding agent.

column2: Trade winds and storms were also more violent.
column3: Trade winds and storms were also more violent.

column2: If ever the moon were close to the earth, it would have to revolve round it in about three hours.
column3: If ever the moon were close to the earth, it would have to revolve round it in about three hours.

column2: If the earth rotated on its axis in three hours, when fluid or pasty, it would be unstable, and begin to separate a portion of itself as a kind of bud, which might then get detached and gradually pushed away by the violent tidal action.
column3: If the earth rotated on its axis in three hours, when fluid or pasty, it would be unstable, and begin to separate a portion of itself as a kind of bud, which might then get detached and gradually pushed away by the violent tidal action.

column2: Hence it is possible that this is the history of the moon.
column3: Hence it is possible that this is the history of the moon.

column2: If so, it is probably an exceptional history.
column3: If so, it is probably an exceptional history.

column2: The planets were not formed from the sun in this way.
column3: The planets were not formed from the sun in this way.

column2: Mars' moons revolve round him more quickly than the planet rotates: hence with them the process is inverted, and they must be approaching him and may some day crash along his surface.
column3: Mars' moons revolve round him more quickly than the planet rotates: hence with them the process is inverted, and they must be approaching him and may some day crash along his surface.

column2: The inner moon is now about 4,000 miles away, and revolves in 7-1/2 hours.
column3: The inner moon is now about four thousand miles away, and revolves in seven to half a hour.

column2: It appears to be about 20 miles in diameter, and weighs therefore, if composed of rock, 40 billion tons.
column3: It appears to be about twenty miles in diameter, and weighs therefore, if composed of rock, forty billion tons.

column2: Mars rotates in 24-1/2 hours.
column3: Mars rotates in twenty four to half a hour.

column2: A similar fate may _possibly_ await our moon ages hence--by reason of the action of terrestrial tides produced by the sun.

column2: LECTURE XVIII
column3: LECTURE eighteen

column2: THE TIDES, AND PLANETARY EVOLUTION
column3: THE TIDES, AND PLANETARY EVOLUTION

column2: In the last lecture we considered the local peculiarities of the tides, the way in which they were formed in open ocean under the action of the moon and the sun, and also the means by which their heights and times could be calculated and predicted years beforehand.
column3: In the last lecture we considered the local peculiarities of the tides, the way in which they were formed in open ocean under the action of the moon and the sun, and also the means by which their heights and times could be calculated and predicted years beforehand.

column2: Towards the end I stated that the subject was very far from being exhausted, and enumerated some of the large and interesting questions which had been left untouched.
column3: Towards the end I stated that the subject was very far from being exhausted, and enumerated some of the large and interesting questions which had been left untouched.

column2: It is with some of these questions that I propose now to deal.
column3: It is with some of these questions that I propose now to deal.

column2: I must begin by reminding you of certain well-known facts, a knowledge of which I may safely assume.
column3: I must begin by reminding you of certain well-known facts, a knowledge of which I may safely assume.

column2: And first we must remind ourselves of the fact that almost all the rocks which form the accessible crust of the earth were deposited by the agency of water.
column3: And first we must remind ourselves of the fact that almost all the rocks which form the accessible crust of the earth were deposited by the agency of water.

column2: Nearly all are arranged in regular strata, and are composed of pulverized materials--materials ground down from pre-existing rocks by some denuding and grinding action.
column3: Nearly all are arranged in regular strata, and are composed of pulverized materials-materials ground down from pre-existing rocks by some denuding and grinding action.

column2: They nearly all contain vestiges of ancient life embedded in them, and these vestiges are mainly of marine origin.
column3: They nearly all contain vestiges of ancient life embedded in them, and these vestiges are mainly of marine origin.

column2: The strata which were once horizontal are now so no longer--they have been tilted and upheaved, bent and distorted, in many places.
column3: The strata which were once horizontal are now so no longer-they have been tilted and upheaved, bent and distorted, in many places.

column2: Some of them again have been metamorphosed by fire, so that their organic remains have been destroyed, and the traces of their aqueous origin almost obliterated.
column3: Some of them again have been metamorphosed by fire, so that their organic remains have been destroyed, and the traces of their aqueous origin almost obliterated.

column2: But still, to the eye of the geologist, all are of aqueous or sedimentary origin: roughly speaking, one may say they were all deposited at the bottom of some ancient sea.
column3: But still, to the eye of the geologist, all are of aqueous or sedimentary origin: roughly speaking, one may say they were all deposited at the bottom of some ancient sea.

column2: The date of their formation no man yet can tell, but that it was vastly distant is certain.
column3: The date of their formation no man yet can tell, but that it was vastly distant is certain.

column2: For the geological era is not over.
column3: For the geological era is not over.

column2: Aqueous action still goes on: still does frost chip the rocks into fragments; still do mountain torrents sweep stone and mud and _debris_ down the gulleys and watercourses; still do rivers erode their channels, and carry mud and silt far out to sea.
column3: Aqueous action still goes on: still does frost chip the rocks into fragments; still do mountain torrents sweep stone and mud and underscore debris underscore down the gulleys and watercourses; still do rivers erode their channels, and carry mud and silt far out to sea.

column2: And, more powerful than any of these agents of denudation, the waves and the tides are still at work along every coast-line, eating away into the cliffs, undermining gradually and submerging acre after acre, and making with the refuse a shingly, or a sandy, or a muddy beach--the nucleus of a new geological formation.
column3: And, more powerful than any of these agents of denudation, the waves and the tides are still at work along every coast line, eating away into the cliffs, undermining gradually and submerging acre after acre, and making with the refuse a shingly, or a sandy, or a muddy beach-the nucleus of a new geological formation.

column2: Of all denuding agents, there can be no doubt that, to the land exposed to them, the waves of the sea are by far the most powerful.
column3: Of all denuding agents, there can be no doubt that, to the land exposed to them, the waves of the sea are by far the most powerful.

column2: Think how they beat and tear, and drive and drag, until even the hardest rock, like basalt, becomes honeycombed into strange galleries and passages--Fingal's Cave, for instance--and the softer parts are crumbled away.
column3: Think how they beat and tear, and drive and drag, until even the hardest rock, like basalt, becomes honeycombed into strange galleries and passages-Fingal's Cave, for instance-and the softer parts are crumbled away.

column2: But the area now exposed to the teeth of the waves is not great. The fury of a winter storm may dash them a little higher than usual, but they cannot reach cliffs 100 feet high.
column3: But the area now exposed to the teeth of the waves is not great. The fury of a winter storm may dash them a little higher than usual, but they cannot reach cliffs one hundred feet high.

column2: They can undermine such cliffs indeed, and then grind the fragments to powder, but their direct action is limited.
column3: They can undermine such cliffs indeed, and then grind the fragments to powder, but their direct action is limited.

column2: Not so limited, however, as they would be without the tides. Consider for a moment the denudation import of the tides: how does the existence of tidal rise and fall affect the geological problem?
column3: Not so limited, however, as they would be without the tides. Consider for a moment the denudation import of the tides: how does the existence of tidal rise and fall affect the geological problem?

column2: The scouring action of the tidal currents themselves is not to be despised.
column3: The scouring action of the tidal currents themselves is not to be despised.

column2: It is the tidal ebb and flow which keeps open channel in the Mersey, for instance.
column3: It is the tidal ebb and flow which keeps open channel in the Mersey, for instance.

column2: But few places are so favourably situated as Liverpool in this respect, and the direct scouring action of the tides in general is not very great.
column3: But few places are so favourably situated as Liverpool in this respect, and the direct scouring action of the tides in general is not very great.

column2: Their geological import mainly consists in this--that they raise and lower the surface waves at regular intervals, so as to apply them to a considerable stretch of coast.
column3: Their geological import mainly consists in this-that they raise and lower the surface waves at regular intervals, so as to apply them to a considerable stretch of coast.

column2: The waves are a great planing machine attacking the land, and the tides raise and lower this planing machine, so that its denuding tooth is applied, now twenty feet vertically above mean level, now twenty feet below.
column3: The waves are a great planing machine attacking the land, and the tides raise and lower this planing machine, so that its denuding tooth is applied, now twenty feet vertically above mean level, now twenty feet below.

column2: Making all allowance for the power of winds and waves, currents, tides, and watercourses, assisted by glacial ice and frost, it must be apparent how slowly the work of forming the rocks is being carried on.
column3: Making all allowance for the power of winds and waves, currents, tides, and watercourses, assisted by glacial ice and frost, it must be apparent how slowly the work of forming the rocks is being carried on.

column2: It goes on steadily, but so slowly that it is estimated to take 6000 years to wear away one foot of the American continent by all the denuding causes combined.
column3: It goes on steadily, but so slowly that it is estimated to take six thousand years to wear away one foot of the American continent by all the denuding causes combined.

column2: To erode a stratum 5000 feet thick will require at this rate thirty million years.
column3: To erode a stratum five thousand feet thick will require at this rate thirty million years.

column2: The age of the earth is not at all accurately known, but there are many grounds for believing it not to be much older than some thirty million years.
column3: The age of the earth is not at all accurately known, but there are many grounds for believing it not to be much older than some thirty million years.

column2: That is to say, not greatly more than this period of time has elapsed since it was in a molten condition.
column3: That is to say, not greatly more than this period of time has elapsed since it was in a molten condition.

column2: It may be as old as a hundred million years, but its age is believed by those most competent to judge to be more likely within this limit than beyond it.
column3: It may be as old as a hundred million years, but its age is believed by those most competent to judge to be more likely within this limit than beyond it.

column2: But if we ask what is the thickness of the rocks which in past times have been formed, and denuded, and re-formed, over and over again, we get an answer, not in feet, but in miles.
column3: But if we ask what is the thickness of the rocks which in past times have been formed, and denuded, and re-formed, over and over again, we get an answer, not in feet, but in miles.

column2: The Laurentian and Huronian rocks of Canada constitute a stratum ten miles thick; and everywhere the rocks at the base of our stratified system are of the most stupendous volume and thickness.
column3: The Laurentian and Huronian rocks of Canada constitute a stratum ten miles thick; and everywhere the rocks at the base of our stratified system are of the most stupendous volume and thickness.

column2: It has always been a puzzle how known agents could have formed these mighty masses, and the only solution offered by geologists was, unlimited time.
column3: It has always been a puzzle how known agents could have formed these mighty masses, and the only solution offered by geologists was, unlimited time.

column2: Given unlimited time, they could, of course, be formed, no matter how slowly the process went on.
column3: Given unlimited time, they could, of course, be formed, no matter how slowly the process went on.

column2: But inasmuch as the time allowable since the earth was cool enough for water to exist on it except as steam is not by any means unlimited, it becomes necessary to look for a far more powerful engine than any now existing; there must have been some denuding agent in those remote ages--ages far more distant from us than the Carboniferous period, far older than any forms of life, fossil or otherwise, ages among the oldest known to geology--a denuding agent must have then existed, far more powerful than any we now know.
column3: But inasmuch as the time allowable since the earth was cool enough for water to exist on it except as steam is not by any means unlimited, it becomes necessary to look for a far more powerful engine than any now existing; there must have been some denuding agent in those remote ages-ages far more distant from us than the Carboniferous period, far older than any forms of life, fossil or otherwise, ages among the oldest known to geology-a denuding agent must have then existed, far more powerful than any we now know.

column2: Such an agent it has been the privilege of astronomy and physics, within the last ten years, to discover.
column3: Such an agent it has been the privilege of astronomy and physics, within the last ten years, to discover.

column2: To this discovery I now proceed to lead up.
column3: To this discovery I now proceed to lead up.

column2: Our fundamental standard of time is the period of the earth's rotation--the length of the day.
column3: Our fundamental standard of time is the period of the earth's rotation-the length of the day.

column2: The earth is our one standard clock: all time is expressed in terms of it, and if it began to go wrong, or if it did not go with perfect uniformity, it would seem a most difficult thing to discover its error, and a most puzzling piece of knowledge to utilize when found.
column3: The earth is our one standard clock: all time is expressed in terms of it, and if it began to go wrong, or if it did not go with perfect uniformity, it would seem a most difficult thing to discover its error, and a most puzzling piece of knowledge to utilize when found.

column2: That it does not go much wrong is proved by the fact that we can calculate back to past astronomical events--ancient eclipses and the like--and we find that the record of their occurrence, as made by the old magi of Chaldaea, is in very close accordance with the result of calculation.
column3: That it does not go much wrong is proved by the fact that we can calculate back to past astronomical events-ancient eclipses and the like-and we find that the record of their occurrence, as made by the old magi of Chaldaea, is in very close accordance with the result of calculation.

column2: One of these famous old eclipses was observed in Babylon about thirty-six centuries ago, and the Chaldaean astronomers have put on record the time of its occurrence.
column3: One of these famous old eclipses was observed in Babylon about thirty six centuries ago, and the Chaldaean astronomers have put on record the time of its occurrence.

column2: Modern astronomers have calculated back when it should have occurred, and the observed time agrees very closely with the actual, but not exactly.
column3: Modern astronomers have calculated back when it should have occurred, and the observed time agrees very closely with the actual, but not exactly.

column3: Why not exactly?

column3: Partly because of the acceleration of the moon's mean motion, as explained in the lecture on Laplace (p. two hundred sixty two).

column3: The orbit of the earth was at that time getting rounder, and so, as a secondary result, the speed of the moon was slightly increasing.

column3: His calculations have been confirmed by Professor Cayley.

column2: This residual discrepancy, when every known cause has been allowed for, amounts to about one hour.
column3: This residual discrepancy, when every known cause has been allowed for, amounts to about one hour.

column2: The eclipse occurred later than calculation warrants.
column3: The eclipse occurred later than calculation warrants.

column2: Now this would have happened from either of two causes, either an acceleration of the moon in her orbit, or a retardation of the earth in her diurnal rotation--a shortening of the month or a lengthening of the day, or both.
column3: Now this would have happened from either of two causes, either an acceleration of the moon in her orbit, or a retardation of the earth in her diurnal rotation-a shortening of the month or a lengthening of the day, or both.

column2: The total discrepancy being, say, two hours, an acceleration of six seconds-per-century per century will in thirty-six centuries amount to one hour; and this, according to the corrected Laplacian theory, is what has occurred. But to account for the other hour some other cause must be sought, and at present it is considered most probably due to a steady retardation of the earth's rotation--a slow, very slow, lengthening of the day.
column3: The total discrepancy being, say, two hours, an acceleration of six seconds per century per century will in thirty six centuries amount to one hour; and this, according to the corrected Laplacian theory, is what has occurred. But to account for the other hour some other cause must be sought, and at present it is considered most probably due to a steady retardation of the earth's rotation-a slow, very slow, lengthening of the day.

column2: The statement that a solar eclipse thirty-six centuries ago was an hour late, means that a place on the earth's surface came into the shadow one hour behind time--that is, had lagged one twenty-fourth part of a revolution.
column3: The statement that a solar eclipse thirty six centuries ago was an hour late, means that a place on the earth's surface came into the shadow one hour behind time-that is, had lagged one twenty fourth part of a revolution.

column2: The earth, therefore, had lost this amount in the course of 3600 x 365-1/4 revolutions.
column3: The earth, therefore, had lost this amount in the course of three thousand six hundred by three hundred sixty five minus one quarter revolutions.

column2: The loss per revolution is exceedingly small, but it accumulates, and at any era the total loss is the sum of all the losses preceding it.
column3: The loss per revolution is exceedingly small, but it accumulates, and at any era the total loss is the sum of all the losses preceding it.

column2: It may be worth while just to explain this point further.
column3: It may be worth while just to explain this point further.

column2: Suppose the earth loses a small piece of time, which I will call an instant, per day; a locality on the earth will come up to a given position one instant late on the first day after an event.
column3: Suppose the earth loses a small piece of time, which I will call an instant, per day; a locality on the earth will come up to a given position one instant late on the first day after an event.

column2: On the next day it would come up two instants late by reason of the previous loss; but it also loses another instant during the course of the second day, and so the total lateness by the end of that day amounts to three instants.
column3: On the next day it would come up two instants late by reason of the previous loss; but it also loses another instant during the course of the second day, and so the total lateness by the end of that day amounts to three instants.

column2: The day after, it will be going slower from the beginning at the rate of two instants a day, it will lose another instant on the fresh day's own account, and it started three instants late; hence the aggregate loss by the end of the third day is 1 + 2 + 3 = 6.
column3: The day after, it will be going slower from the beginning at the rate of two instants a day, it will lose another instant on the fresh day's own account, and it started three instants late; hence the aggregate loss by the end of the third day is one plus two plus three equals six.

column2: By the end of the fourth day the whole loss will be 1 + 2 + 3 + 4, and so on.
column3: By the end of the fourth day the whole loss will be one plus two plus three plus four, and so on.

column2: Wherefore by merely losing one instant every day the total loss in _n_ days is (1 + 2 + 3 + ... + _n_) instants, which amounts to 1/2_n_ (_n_ + 1) instants; or practically, when _n_ is big, to 1/2n^2.
column3: Wherefore by merely losing one instant every day the total loss in underscore n underscore days is (one plus two plus three plus ... plus underscore n underscore) instants, which amounts to one half underscore n underscore (underscore n underscore plus one) instants; or practically, when underscore n underscore is big, to one half n squared.

column2: Now in thirty-six centuries there have been 3600 x 365-1/4 days, and the total loss has amounted to an hour; hence the length of "an instant," the loss per diem, can be found from the equation 1/2(3600 x 365)^2 instants = 1 hour; whence one "instant" equals the 240 millionth part of a second.
column3: Now in thirty six centuries there have been three thousand six hundred by three hundred sixty five minus one quarter days, and the total loss has amounted to an hour; hence the length of "an instant," the loss per diem, can be found from the equation one half(three thousand six hundred by three hundred sixty five)squared instants equals one hour; whence one "instant" equals the two hundred forty millionth part of a second.

column2: This minute quantity represents the retardation of the earth per day.
column3: This minute quantity represents the retardation of the earth per day.

column2: In a year the aggregate loss mounts up to 1/3600th part of a second, in a century to about three seconds, and in thirty-six centuries to an hour.
column3: In a year the aggregate loss mounts up to one three thousand six hundredth part of a second, in a century to about three seconds, and in thirty six centuries to an hour.

column2: But even at the end of the thirty-six centuries the day is barely any longer; it is only 3600 x 365 instants, that is 1/180th of a second, longer than it was at the beginning.
column3: But even at the end of the thirty six centuries the day is barely any longer; it is only three thousand six hundred by three hundred sixty five instants, that is one one hundred eightieth of a second, longer than it was at the beginning.

column2: And even a million years ago, unless the rate of loss was different (as it probably was), the day would only be thirty-five minutes shorter, though by that time the aggregate loss, as measured by the apparent lateness of any perfectly punctual event reckoned now, would have amounted to nine years. (These numbers are to be taken as illustrative, not as precisely representing terrestrial fact.)

column2: What can have caused the slowing down?

column2: Swelling of the earth by reason of accumulation of meteoric dust might do something, but probably very little.
column3: Swelling of the earth by reason of accumulation of meteoric dust might do something, but probably very little.

column2: Contraction of the earth as it goes on cooling would act in the opposite direction, and probably more than counterbalance the dust effect.

column2: The problem is thus not a simple one, for there are several disturbing causes, and for none of them are the data enough to base a quantitative estimate upon; but one certain agent in lengthening the day, and almost certainly the main agent, is to be found in the tides.
column3: The problem is thus not a simple one, for there are several disturbing causes, and for none of them are the data enough to base a quantitative estimate upon; but one certain agent in lengthening the day, and almost certainly the main agent, is to be found in the tides.

column2: Remember that the tidal humps were produced as the prolateness of a sphere whirled round and round a fixed centre, like a football whirled by a string.
column3: Remember that the tidal humps were produced as the prolateness of a sphere whirled round and round a fixed centre, like a football whirled by a string.

column2: These humps are pulled at by the moon, and the earth rotates on its axis against this pull.
column3: These humps are pulled at by the moon, and the earth rotates on its axis against this pull.

column2: Hence it tends to be constantly, though very slightly, dragged back.
column3: Hence it tends to be constantly, though very slightly, dragged back.

column2: In so far as the tidal wave is allowed to oscillate freely, it will swing with barely any maintaining force, giving back at one quarter-swing what it has received at the previous quarter; but in so far as it encounters friction, which it does in all channels where there is an actual ebb and flow of the water, it has to receive more than it gives back, and the balance of energy has to be made up to it, or the tides would cease.
column3: In so far as the tidal wave is allowed to oscillate freely, it will swing with barely any maintaining force, giving back at one quarter swing what it has received at the previous quarter; but in so far as it encounters friction, which it does in all channels where there is an actual ebb and flow of the water, it has to receive more than it gives back, and the balance of energy has to be made up to it, or the tides would cease.

column2: The energy of the tides is, in fact, continually being dissipated by friction, and all the energy so dissipated is taken from the rotation of the earth.
column3: The energy of the tides is, in fact, continually being dissipated by friction, and all the energy so dissipated is taken from the rotation of the earth.

column2: If tidal energy were utilized by engineers, the machines driven would be really driven at the expense of the earth's rotation: it would be a mode of harnessing the earth and using the moon as fixed point or fulcrum; the moon pulling at the tidal protuberance, and holding it still as the earth rotates, is the mechanism whereby the energy is extracted, the handle whereby the friction brake is applied.
column3: If tidal energy were utilized by engineers, the machines driven would be really driven at the expense of the earth's rotation: it would be a mode of harnessing the earth and using the moon as fixed point or fulcrum; the moon pulling at the tidal protuberance, and holding it still as the earth rotates, is the mechanism whereby the energy is extracted, the handle whereby the friction brake is applied.

column2: Winds and ocean currents have no such effect (as Mr. Fronde in _Oceania_ supposes they have), because they are all accompanied by a precisely equal counter-current somewhere else, and no internal rearrangement of fluid can affect the motion of a mass as a whole; but the tides are in different case, being produced, not by internal inequalities of temperature, but by a straightforward pull from an external body.
column3: Winds and ocean currents have no such effect (as mr Fronde in underscore Oceania underscore supposes they have), because they are all accompanied by a precisely equal counter current somewhere else, and no internal rearrangement of fluid can affect the motion of a mass as a whole; but the tides are in different case, being produced, not by internal inequalities of temperature, but by a straightforward pull from an external body.

column2: After having got up the whirl, the hand holding the string may remain almost fixed at the centre of the circle, and the motion will continue steadily; but if the hand be moved so as always to pull the string a little in advance of the centre, the speed of whirl will increase, the elastic will be more and more stretched, until the whirling ball is describing a much larger circle. But in this case it will likewise be going faster--distance and speed increase together.

column2: It does not obey any of Kepler's laws, and so it does not obey the one which now concerns us, viz. the third; which practically states that the further a planet is from the centre the slower it goes; its velocity varies inversely with the square root of its distance (p. 74).

column2: It is superposed upon all periodic changes, and, though it seems smaller than they, it is more inexorable. column2: The bigger one we now call earth, the smaller we now call moon.

column2: But they are unstable, and cannot go on thus: they must either separate or collapse.

column3: Some disturbing cause acts again, and the smaller mass begins to revolve less rapidly.

column2: Tides at once begin--gigantic tides of molten lava hundreds of miles high; tides not in free ocean, for there was none then, but in the pasty mass of the entire earth.
column3: Tides at once begin-gigantic tides of molten lava hundreds of miles high; tides not in free ocean, for there was none then, but in the pasty mass of the entire earth.

column2: Immediately the series of changes I have described begins, the speed of rotation gets slackened, the moon's mass gets pushed further and further away, and its time of revolution grows rapidly longer.
column3: Immediately the series of changes I have described begins, the speed of rotation gets slackened, the moon's mass gets pushed further and further away, and its time of revolution grows rapidly longer.

column2: The changes went on rapidly at first, because the tides were so gigantic; but gradually, and by slow degrees, the bodies get more distant, and the rate of change more moderate.
column3: The changes went on rapidly at first, because the tides were so gigantic; but gradually, and by slow degrees, the bodies get more distant, and the rate of change more moderate.

column2: Until, after the lapse of ages, we find the day twenty-four hours long, the moon 240,000 miles distant, revolving in 27-1/3 days, and the tides only existing in the water of the ocean, and only a few feet high.

column2: This is the era we call "to-day."

column3: Mercury one thousand one hundred twenty one Venus two thousand three hundred thirty nine Earth one thousand Mars three hundred four Jupiter two thousand one hundred thirty six Saturn one thousand thirty three Uranus twenty one Neptune nine

column2: The power of all of them is very feeble, and by acting on different sides they usually partly neutralize each other's action; but occasionally they get all on one side, and in that case some perceptible effect may be produced; the probable effect seems likely to be a gentle heaving tide in the solar surface, with breaking up of any incipient crust; and such an effect may be considered as evidenced periodically by the great increase in the number of solar spots which then break out.
column3: The power of all of them is very feeble, and by acting on different sides they usually partly neutralize each other's action; but occasionally they get all on one side, and in that case some perceptible effect may be produced; the probable effect seems likely to be a gentle heaving tide in the solar surface, with breaking up of any incipient crust; and such an effect may be considered as evidenced periodically by the great increase in the number of solar spots which then break out.

column2: The solar tides are, however, much too small to appreciably push any planet away, hence we are not to suppose that the planets originated by budding from the sun, in contradiction of the nebular hypothesis.
column3: The solar tides are, however, much too small to appreciably push any planet away, hence we are not to suppose that the planets originated by budding from the sun, in contradiction of the nebular hypothesis.

column2: Nor is it necessary to assume that the satellites, as a class, originated in the way ours did; though they may have done so.
column3: Nor is it necessary to assume that the satellites, as a class, originated in the way ours did; though they may have done so.

column2: They were more probably secondary rings.
column3: They were more probably secondary rings.

column2: Our moon differs from other satellites in being exceptionally large compared with the size of its primary; it is as big as some of the moons of Jupiter and Saturn.
column3: Our moon differs from other satellites in being exceptionally large compared with the size of its primary; it is as big as some of the moons of Jupiter and Saturn.

column2: The earth is the only one of the small planets that has an appreciable moon, and hence there is nothing forced or unnatural in supposing that it may have had an exceptional history.
column3: The earth is the only one of the small planets that has an appreciable moon, and hence there is nothing forced or unnatural in supposing that it may have had an exceptional history.

column2: Evidently, however, tidal phenomena must be taken into consideration in any treatment of the solar system through enormous length of time, and it will probably play a large part in determining its future.
column3: Evidently, however, tidal phenomena must be taken into consideration in any treatment of the solar system through enormous length of time, and it will probably play a large part in determining its future.

column2: When Laplace and Lagrange investigated the question of the stability or instability of the solar system, they did so on the hypothesis that the bodies composing it were rigid.
column3: When Laplace and Lagrange investigated the question of the stability or instability of the solar system, they did so on the hypothesis that the bodies composing it were rigid.

column2: They reached a grand conclusion--that all the mutual perturbations of the solar system were periodic--that whatever changes were going on would reach a maximum and then begin to diminish; then increase again, then diminish, and so on.
column3: They reached a grand conclusion-that all the mutual perturbations of the solar system were periodic-that whatever changes were going on would reach a maximum and then begin to diminish; then increase again, then diminish, and so on.

column2: The system was stable, and its changes were merely like those of a swinging pendulum.
column3: The system was stable, and its changes were merely like those of a swinging pendulum.

column2: But this conclusion is not final.
column3: But this conclusion is not final.

column2: The hypothesis that the bodies are rigid is not strictly true: and directly tidal deformation is taken into consideration it is perceived to be a potent factor, able in the long run to upset all their calculations.
column3: The hypothesis that the bodies are rigid is not strictly true: and directly tidal deformation is taken into consideration it is perceived to be a potent factor, able in the long run to upset all their calculations.

column2: But it is so utterly and inconceivably minute--it only produces an appreciable effect after millions of years--whereas the ordinary perturbations go through their swings in some hundred thousand years or so at the most.
column3: But it is so utterly and inconceivably minute-it only produces an appreciable effect after millions of years-whereas the ordinary perturbations go through their swings in some hundred thousand years or so at the most.

column2: Granted it is small, but it is terribly persistent; and it always acts in one direction.
column3: Granted it is small, but it is terribly persistent; and it always acts in one direction.

column2: Never does it cease: never does it begin to act oppositely and undo what it has done.
column3: Never does it cease: never does it begin to act oppositely and undo what it has done.

column2: It is like the perpetual dropping of water. There may be only one drop in a twelvemonth, but leave it long enough, and the hardest stone must be worn away at last.
column3: It is like the perpetual dropping of water. There may be only one drop in a twelvemonth, but leave it long enough, and the hardest stone must be worn away at last.

column2: We have been speaking of millions of years somewhat familiarly; but what, after all, is a million years that we should not speak familiarly of it?
column3: We have been speaking of millions of years somewhat familiarly; but what, after all, is a million years that we should not speak familiarly of it?

column2: It is longer than our lifetime, it is true.
column3: It is longer than our lifetime, it is true.

column2: To the ephemeral insects whose lifetime is an hour, a year might seem an awful period, the mid-day sun might seem an almost stationary body, the changes of the seasons would be unknown, everything but the most fleeting and rapid changes would appear permanent and at rest.
column3: To the ephemeral insects whose lifetime is an hour, a year might seem an awful period, the mid day sun might seem an almost stationary body, the changes of the seasons would be unknown, everything but the most fleeting and rapid changes would appear permanent and at rest.

column2: Conversely, if our life-period embraced myriads of aeons, things which now seem permanent would then appear as in a perpetual state of flux.
column3: Conversely, if our life period embraced myriads of aeons, things which now seem permanent would then appear as in a perpetual state of flux.

column2: A continent would be sometimes dry, sometimes covered with ocean; the stars we now call fixed would be moving visibly before our eyes; the earth would be humming on its axis like a top, and the whole of human history might seem as fleeting as a cloud of breath on a mirror.
column3: A continent would be sometimes dry, sometimes covered with ocean; the stars we now call fixed would be moving visibly before our eyes; the earth would be humming on its axis like a top, and the whole of human history might seem as fleeting as a cloud of breath on a mirror.

column2: Evolution is always a slow process.
column3: Evolution is always a slow process.

column2: To evolve such an animal as a greyhound from its remote ancestors, according to Mr. Darwin, needs immense tracts of time; and if the evolution of some feeble animal crawling on the surface of this planet is slow, shall the stately evolution of the planetary orbs themselves be hurried?
column3: To evolve such an animal as a greyhound from its remote ancestors, according to mr Darwin, needs immense tracts of time; and if the evolution of some feeble animal crawling on the surface of this planet is slow, shall the stately evolution of the planetary orbs themselves be hurried?

column2: It may be that we are able to trace the history of the solar system for some thousand million years or so; but for how much longer time must it not have a history--a history, and also a future--entirely beyond our ken?
column3: It may be that we are able to trace the history of the solar system for some thousand million years or so; but for how much longer time must it not have a history-a history, and also a future-entirely beyond our ken?
